data.name: Having valuable one-on-ones
data.description: Meeting regularly with your manager to set and track goals related to your career progression.

recommendations.markdown: Anyone working at a company where they report directly to a manager needs to be able to use one-on-one conversations with their manager to take control over their career path within that company.

Do you have regular one-on-one meetings with your manager where you align on your career trajectory and keep track of your professional development? Someone who excels at this skill keeps track of agenda items for their next one-on-one, and [sets goals](https://tessa.commit.community/skills/19/) that their manager can hold them accountable to.

There are guides directed both at managers and their reports for how to have valuable one-on-one meetings. Read guides for both sides! Align with your manager on the expectations of both sides. This guide on [Conducting Effective and Regular One-on-Ones](https://moz.com/blog/conducting-effective-and-regular-oneonones) is a great place to start.
Set a schedule to have one-on-one meetings with your manager. A half-hour meeting every week, or forty-five minutes every two weeks are common schedules you could try. Never miss these meetings.
During your daily work, take notes of questions you want to ask your manager.
Come up with ideas for topics to discuss with your manager. Julia Evans compiled some [1:1 topic ideas](https://jvns.ca/blog/2015/03/06/1-1-topic-ideas/) with links to more resources.
